abstract.text: A view that arranges an array of views horizontally or vertically and updates their placement and sizing when the window size changes.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A stack view employs Auto Layout (the system’s constraint-based layout feature) to arrange and align an array of views according to your specification. To use a stack view effectively, you need to understand the basics of Auto Layout constraints as described in

A stack view supports vertical and horizontal layouts and interacts dynamically with window resizing and Cocoa animations. You can easily reconfigure the contents of a stack view at runtime. That is, after you create and configure a stack view in Interface Builder, you can add or remove views dynamically without explicitly working with layout constraints. For example, if you configure a stack view with three checkboxes and dynamically add a fourth, the stack view automatically adds constraints as needed, according to the stack view’s configuration. The new checkbox gains dynamic layout configuration from the stack view.
Stack views are nestable: a stack view is a valid element in the
array of another stack view.
Do not add views or constraints to a stack view’s private views. A stack view’s private views might change in future versions of macOS and are not guaranteed to be encoded or decoded with the
class.
For more information on
, see
A stack view has three so-called
gravity areas

that each identify a section of the stack view’s layout. A horizontal stack view, which is the default type, has a leading, a center, and a trailing gravity area. The ordering of these areas depends on the value of the stack view’s
property (inherited from the

class). In a left to right language, the leading gravity area in a horizontal stack view is on the left. To enforce a left to right layout independently of language, explicitly set the layout direction by calling the inherited
method on your stack view instance.
To specify vertical layout, use the
property and the
constant from the
enumeration. In a vertical stack view, the gravity areas always are top, center, and bottom.

A stack view can automatically detach and reattach its views in response to layout changes, such as window resizing performed by the user, or resizing/repositioning of another view in the same view hierarchy. A view in a detached state is not present in the stack view’s view hierarchy, but it still consumes memory. A view that is hidden, but not detached, remains part of the view hierarchy and continues to participate in Auto Layout, but it is not visible and doesn’t receive input events.
To allow views to detach, set the so-called
clipping resistance
for a stack view to a value lower than its default of
. See the
method.
You can influence which views detach first (and reattach last). Do this by setting the so-called
visibility priority
for each view whose detachment order you want to specify. A view with a lower visibility priority detaches before one with a higher priority, and reattaches after it. See the
enumeration and the
method.
To explicitly detach a view from a stack view, call the
method with a value of
. To explicitly reattach a view to a stack view, call the same method with a value of
. If you hide a view that belongs to a stack view (by setting the view’s
property to
), the view detaches from the stack view by default. Use the
property to change the default behavior.
The system calls a stack view delegate method when a view is about to be detached and when a view has been reattached, giving you the opportunity to run code at those times. See

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
A required constraint.
A view that arranges an array of views horizontally or vertically and updates their placement and sizing when the window size changes.
The gravity areas available in a stack view.
The various Auto Layout priorities for a view in the stack view to remain attached.
The default value, and maximum Auto Layout priority, that results in a view never detaching from the stack view.
The minimum Auto Layout priority that forces a view to detach from the stack view.
Adds the specified view to the end of the arranged subviews list.
Adds a view to the end of the stack view gravity area.
The view alignment within the stack view.
The array of views arranged by the stack view.
Returns the Auto Layout priority for resisting clipping of views in the stack view when Auto Layout attempts to reduce the stack view’s size.
Returns the custom spacing, in points, between a specified view in the stack view and the view that follows it.
The delegate object for the stack view.
An array that contains the detached views from all the stack view’s gravity areas.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the stack view removes hidden views from its view hierarchy.
The geometric padding, in points, inside the stack view, surrounding its views.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the spacing between adjacent views should be equal to each other.
Returns the Auto Layout priority for the stack view to minimize its size to fit its contained views as closely as possible, for a specified user interface axis.
Creates and returns a stack view with a specified array of views.
Adds the provided view to the array of arranged subviews at the specified index.
Adds a view to a stack view gravity area at a specified index position.
The horizontal or vertical layout direction of the stack view.
Removes the provided view from the stack’s array of arranged subviews.
Removes a specified view from the stack view.
Sets the Auto Layout priority for resisting clipping of views in the stack view when Auto Layout attempts to reduce the stack view’s size.
Specifies the custom spacing, in points, between a specified view and the view that follows it in the stack view.
Sets the Auto Layout priority for the stack view to minimize its size, for a specified user interface axis.
Specifies an array of views for a specified gravity area in the stack view, replacing any previous views in that area.
Sets the Auto Layout priority for a view to remain attached to the stack view when Auto Layout reduces the stack view’s size.
The minimum spacing, in points, between adjacent views in the stack view.
The array of views owned by the stack view.
Returns the array of views in the specified gravity area in the stack view.
Returns the visibility priority for a specified view in the stack view.
A set of methods you use to respond to a stack view detaching and reattaching views.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
The stack view layout directions, and user interface axes for hugging priority and clipping resistance.
The vertical orientation.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
A Boolean value indicating whether the view is hidden.
The layout direction for content in the view.
Group individual views in your app’s user interface into a scrollable stack view.

abstract.text: An abstract class that serves as the basis for objects that enable archiving and distribution of other objects.
A true value.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
